Allow me to summarize.

This clip is Part 1 of Jaron, in his own words, muddled and confused though they may be, telling us that virtually every bit of shade-tree psychoanalysis we've ever embarked upon was 100% accurate. This is a young man describing dissociative disorder from the inside. People suffering from it are almost without exception not only victims of repressed abuse, but abuse of the most horrific sort. In Jaron's case, that abuse was of a psychosexual variety. He was told he was something he was not, made to despise his own body, his own sexuality.

It is all too easy to imagine his mother, who wanted another girl, who was told by a "psychic" that she was going to have one, taking Jazz aside, showing him her naked form, and telling him that this is what he was meant to be, that he was a failure, a disappointment, until he became that, then spending his entire childhood reinforcing that fantasy through means both twistedly "positive" and the very darkest sort of negative. Students of Freud will recognize this as a variation of the Primal Scene, Jazz becoming aware of his mother's sexuality and sexual distinctions from himself, but in a way meant to instill a sense of wrongness, brokenness within his developing mind.

>>180563327
Jeannette has spent the entirety of Jazz's life fostering in him a sense of complete reliance. While his siblings were given the "normal" childhood of being sent out to face the brutal, Darwinistic world of childhood and public education as the elder brothers and sister of a child put forth as the face of "trans children," he was coddled, sheltered, virtual "schooled," told repeatedly what a special, fragile little flower he was, and while he spent the bulk of his life only subliminally aware of how different his upbringing had been, his adolescent brushes with reality brought it to the forefront of his confused, manipulated mind. "The world is cruel and dangerous," he'd been told, and while any other child(including his sister, his brothers) would have been encouraged to find the bravery to face it, Jaron was ever encouraged to retreat - from conflict, from reality, back to the womb-like safety of home, of … mother. While it is a matter of conjecture how conscious Jeannette was of what she was instilling in him, the end result is inarguable in its reality - a palpable, nigh-unbreakable codependency between mother and child, one of the hallmarks of the syndrome known as Munchausen by Proxy.

At some point, possibly during her "special" pregnancy with the twins, Jeannette became addicted to the attention she was receiving. It is not difficult to imagine the celebration she received in response to her bravery, going under the knife as she did to save her unborn children. But then came Jaron - boring, uneventful, perfectly healthy little Jaron. Thus was born in her subconscious the desire to somehow elevate this final child, this final source of attention, and what a phenomenal coincidence that it was in a way that aligned both with her desire to return to the world of film production and to have another little girl. A "special" little girl. Born into a household where his male indentity was effectively stillborn, poor little Jaron never stood a chance.

Like the autogynephilic porn addicts that "become" transgender later in life, Jazz is also not truly transgender. No, his psychosis is of a different sort altogether. Within his familial dynamic, it's all about attention-seeking behaviors. He's not primarily interested in just becoming a woman, but rather a *specific* woman. He's a usurper of identity.

Jazz didn't want to become a woman; he wanted to become his sister. In fact, even the name he chose was stolen from her, Ari having played the role of Jasmine in a school production of "Aladdin." You can see echoes of this behavior in his abortive and confused relationship with a young woman named "Michaela." Like his sister, Michaela has qualities that Jazz not only admires, but wishes to steal, to make his own. He doesn't cherish Michaela's feminine qualities and her talents; he covets them. Like his sister, Michaela is attractive. Like his sister, Michaela is also a talented singer. That's why it was unsurprising that when Jazz briefly fixated on her, we observed some of his recurrent behaviors resurfacing. He stole from her. He stole credit for her work on a song on which they had "collaborated." He even stole her name after a fashion when he, in a dark inversion of the event from his childhood, used her name for a character he portrayed in a drama. He stole her work, stole her name and twisted it in a vain attempt to in some way make it his own, and these are the very least of the things he would steal.

In the second game there's survivor cult in the outskirts of the ruins of Seattle (This is 25 years after the outbreak) that rejects modern technology and has reverted to a more primitive lifestyle, they don't use guns, cars, machines or modern building material. They're also fanatically religious, and follow a woman who claimed to have visions shortly after the outbreak and claims the fungus was a punishment for mankinds sins. There are some elements of Christianity and New age religions mixed in in to it. They ritually scar their own faces and have incredibly strict gender roles. All the males are assigned to be warriors and have shaved heads. All the females are forcibly married to a husband have to follow their command, are assigned housework and are forbidden to cut their hair.

In the game you come across a young "boy" with shaved head called Lev, you save him from his fellow cult members who tried to kidnap/kill him. Eventually you learn that it's a girl who looked up to her older brother, got forcibly married to some older man and so ran away and shaved her head.

The story makes it obvious what's going on eventually but it doesn't beat you over the head about them being essentially trans.

Druids are proficient with the following weapons: club, dagger, dart, quarterstaff, scimitar, sickle, shortspear, sling, and spear. They are also proficient with all natural attacks (claw, bite, and so forth) of any form they assume with wild shape.

Druids are proficient with light and medium armor but are prohibited from wearing metal armor; thus, they may wear only padded, leather, or hide armor. (A druid may also wear wooden armor that has been altered by the ironwood spell so that it functions as though it were steel. See the ironwood spell description) Druids are proficient with shields (except tower shields) but must use only wooden ones.

A druid who wears prohibited armor or carries a prohibited shield is unable to cast druid spells or use any of her supernatural or spell-like class abilities while doing so and for 24 hours thereafter.

>>180557246
Human eyes have three types of cones that can identify combinations of red, blue, and green.
Dogs possess only two types of cones and can only discern blue and yellow - this limited color perception is called dichromatic vision.
Many invertebrates have color vision. Honeybees and bumblebees have trichromatic color vision which is insensitive to red but sensitive to ultraviolet.
ange of wavelengths of light stimulates each of these receptor types to varying degrees. The brain combines the information from each type of receptor to give rise to different perceptions of different wavelengths of light.
The opsins (photopigments) present in the L and M cones are encoded on the X chromosome; defective encoding of these leads to the two most common forms of color blindness. The OPN1LW gene, which encodes the opsin present in the L cones, is highly polymorphic;
The opsins (photopigments) present in the L and M cones are encoded on the X chromosome; defective encoding of these leads to the two most common forms of color blindness. The OPN1LW gene, which encodes the opsin present in the L cones, is highly polymorphic;

>Normalized response spectra of human cones
Presented here are results comparing electrophysiological measurements of single human cones with the expressed cone pigment gene sequences from the same retina. In a sample of eight long-wavelength sensitive cone (L cone) spectra obtained from five donors the precise spectral sensitivities, measured in situ, of the two most commonly occurring spectral variants were determined. The peak sensitivity of the Lser180 cone was 563 nm while that of the Lala180 cone was 559 nm.
The photopigment in the outer segment of the cone consists of two covalently linked parts, a protein called opsin and a chromophore based on retinal, an aldehyde of vitamin A. It is the latter that provides light sensitivity by isomerizing from 11-cis to all-trans forms. This leads to the activation of a guanine nucleotide-binding pro- tein (G-protein), transducin, and a cascade of molecular events that result in a change in the rate of neurotrans- mitter release from the receptor to other neurons in the retina. In the course of the cascade, the signal provided by photon absorption is greatly amplified.

>>180557246
The spectral sensitivities of the cones, in vivo, have been estimated by many different methods. Historically, the most important method is based on psychophysical .
color-matching, in which a mixture of three fixed primary lights is matched against a monochromatic light of vari- able wavelength and constant radiant power. These data form the basis of the system of colorimetry standardized by the Commission Internationale de l’Eclairage (CIE). In the normal trichromatic eye, such color-matching func- tions yield a family of spectral sensitivities that are a linear transformation of the unknown cone spectral sensitivities. This transformation is not unique in that it varies with the choice of primaries, but data obtained from dichromatic and sometimes monochromatic observers, who have, re- spectively, only two and one of the three normal cone types, provide good estimates of these so-called funda-mental spectral sensitivities.
Other psychophysical methods of estimation involve selectively chromatically adapting the three cone types by a background light and measuring the spectral sensitivity of the most sensitive color mechanism at or near its threshold level of response, a technique associated pri- marily with W. S. Stiles.
Nonpsychophysical but noninvasive methods of in vivo estimation include retinal densitometry (i.e., fundus spectral reflectometry) and electroretinography. In retinal densitometry, differences in reflectance of the fundus are measured, at various wavelengths, before and after selectively bleaching the cone pigments. The method is limited by its low signal-to-noise ratio and the need to distinguish between signals from L and M cones. It is also difficult to obtain signals reliably from S cones. In electroretinography, the summed electrical response of the retina to a flickering light is measured with a corneal electrode.This method provides a much larger dynamic range, of several log units, along with a good signal-to- noise ratio

posts.com:
Honestly the show is good. There is this natural process, Simpsons expresses it, a show tries to find its core or the characters and then it grows from there. So Simpsons s1-2 is pretty straightforward, trying to find its style and write a really good episode. Once they figure the episode out they start expanding, what other shapes can this be stretched into. So you get season 3-4 and Simpsons becomes a very “written” show with everything working well enough they can elevate the writing. Then a cycle starts of trying to top what came before and experimenting with shit. Season 5-6 is really trying to elevate, they shot Mr burns, but season 7-8 have some really experimental bits like homer doing the hallucinogenic pepper.

So watching Simpsons now I thought the good episodes ended pretty early but there’s like 10 more seasons that are pretty good.

IASP starts a bit more grounded and they start pulling out the jenga blocks of intelligence and sanity. Before long they had a fairly silly show but for the most part episodes tell good, self-contained stories with a theme and a point. I think any wokism is normally just an excuse, you grew out of their silliness and realize that you might have not totally got the jokes in the show. The gang aren’t good people, the show always saw them as antagonists. As the show expands they have to do ever more extreme things to get attention and some day the pendulum swing would end up with something you liked getting skewered.

My man, that is the subjective test definition of entrapment. Under that test police action must cause the suspect to commit the crime and the suspect must prove that he was not predisposed to commit the crime.

In the objective test the court would judge if the police conduct would have caused an average law-abiding citizen to commit the crime.
The suspects fail on both counts in the show (though I admit it seems pretty close at time). You don't actually know what entrapment is.

>Director Guillermo del Toro and screenwriter Matthew Robbins wrote a screenplay based on Lovecraft's story in 2006, but had trouble getting Warner Bros. to finance the project. Del Toro wrote, "The studio is very nervous about the cost and it not having a love story or a happy ending, but it's impossible to do either in the Lovecraft universe."In July 2010, it was announced that the film would be made in 3D and that James Cameron would become producer, and Tom Cruise was attached to star. This "was a startling prospect considering Lovecraft's tale had long been considered unfilmable." Del Toro confirmed that the film would begin production as early as May 2011 and start filming in June. However, in March 2011, it was announced that "Universal Studios refused to greenlight the project due to del Toro's insistence that it be released with an R rating rather than a PG-13. "In 2012, del Toro posted that, due to the resemblance in premise with the Ridley Scott film Prometheus, the project would probably face a "long pause—if not demise".[32][33] In 2013, del Toro stated in an interview that he would try one more time to get the picture made. In December 2021, Del Toro revealed that At the Mountains of Madness was pitched to Netflix, after signing a multi-year deal with the streaming service in 2020. The filmmaker stated: “Take a wild guess which were the first projects I presented, you know? I went through the cupboard and found ‘Monte Cristo’ and ‘Mountains of Madness.’ Those were a couple of the ones I presented first.” Del Toro further iterated that he intends to rewrite the script and make it a smaller, weirder and more esoteric version in respect to the scenes that he has left out before. Del Toro cast doubt if Tom Cruise will still star in the project in the foreseeable future due to his age.
It sounds incredible, it would be nice to see Cruise starring in horror films as he gets older. Peter Jackson or Spielberg would also be good directors.

posts.com:
1 Corinthians 13:12 contains the phrase βλέπομεν γὰρ ἄρτι δι' ἐσόπτρου ἐν αἰνίγματι, blepomen gar arti di esoptrou en ainigmati, which was translated in the 1560 Geneva Bible as "For now we see through a glass darkly" (without a comma). This wording was used in the 1611 KJV, which added a comma before "darkly".[4] This passage has inspired the titles of many works, with and without the comma.

The Greek word ἐσόπτρου, esoptrou (genitive; nominative: ἔσοπτρον, esoptron), here translated "glass", is ambiguous, possibly referring to a mirror or a lens. Influenced by Strong's Concordance, many modern translations conclude that this word refers specifically to a mirror.[5] Example English language translations include:

"Now we see but a poor reflection as in a mirror" (New International Version)
"What we see now is like a dim image in a mirror" (Good News Bible)

So to some, the Fireflies are terminally naive, and to others they're the only real source of hope that there is. And seeing as how the point of the entire game(s) is that survival without hope is pointless, and that it barely (if at all) matters whether the hope is legitimate or not, yeah it makes sense that they're treated with some importance.

A lot of it is geographic. The US historically transports freight via boat because it's much, much cheaper than any alternative and America has a ton of navigable rivers.

I'm actually dubious about this being a product of that because the freight train network is the one that works well enough, it's passenger train networks in the US which are nonexistent, and because we just had three derailings in the span of a few days. That doesn't sound like breakdown, it sounds like sabotage.

posts.com:
While Highlander is a pretty good show, it should be noted that the end of season six/start of season seven has a MASSIVE shark jump moment. In a plot thread that Joss Whedon ripped off for Buffy via the "First Evil", the show introduced in the season finale a Zoroastrian demon/devil that was the ultimate evil of existence that can take the form of the dead and manipulated Duncan into killing his sidekick/protege Richie via cutting off his head.

This was to set up the final season being Duncan vs the Zoroastrian Devil (with the season six finale basically establishing that Duncan was the chosen one to beat him) but SOMETHING happened off-camera to make the writers backpeddle the fuck over the whole thing with two REALLY badly written episodes that launched season seven that downgraded the apocalyptic threat of the demon and had Duncan beat the demon via performing i-ching yoga while the Zoroastrian devil (which can't physically touch people) rages around Duncan and tries impotently to cut him with his various forms phantom swords before vanishing for good.

This fucked shit up so badly that when the show got canceled, they had to do a two-part series finale with some literal who characters from a previous episode as the big bad since they blew their load on their planned big bad for the series finale.
